prompt_text:
haz un resumen en español del siguietne texto:
"How do you explain when things don't go as we assume? Or better, how do you explain when others are able to achieve things that seem to defy all of the assumptions? For example: Why is Apple so innovative? Year after year, after year, they're more innovative than all their competition. And yet, they're just a computer company. They're just like everyone else. They have the same access to the same talent, the same agencies, the same consultants, the same media. Then why is it that they seem to have something different? Why is it that Martin Luther King led the Civil Rights Movement? He wasn't the only man who suffered in pre-civil rights America, and he certainly wasn't the only great orator of the day. Why him? And why is it that the Wright brothers were able to figure out controlled, powered man flight when there were certainly other teams who were better qualified, better funded -- and they didn't achieve powered man flight, and the Wright brothers beat them to it. There's something else at play here.

01:06
About three and a half years ago, I made a discovery. And this discovery profoundly changed my view on how I thought the world worked, and it even profoundly changed the way in which I operate in it. As it turns out, there's a pattern. As it turns out, all the great inspiring leaders and organizations in the world, whether it's Apple or Martin Luther King or the Wright brothers, they all think, act and communicate the exact same way. And it's the complete opposite to everyone else. All I did was codify it, and it's probably the world's simplest idea. I call it the golden circle.

01:56
Why? How? What? This little idea explains why some organizations and some leaders are able to inspire where others aren't. Let me define the terms really quickly. Every single person, every single organization on the planet knows what they do, 100 percent. Some know how they do it, whether you call it your differentiated value proposition or your proprietary process or your USP. But very, very few people or organizations know why they do what they do. And by "why" I don't mean "to make a profit." That's a result. It's always a result. By "why," I mean: What's your purpose? What's your cause? What's your belief? Why does your organization exist? Why do you get out of bed in the morning? And why should anyone care? As a result, the way we think, we act, the way we communicate is from the outside in, it's obvious. We go from the clearest thing to the fuzziest thing. But the inspired leaders and the inspired organizations -- regardless of their size, regardless of their industry -- all think, act and communicate from the inside out.

03:02
Let me give you an example. I use Apple because they're easy to understand and everybody gets it. If Apple were like everyone else, a marketing message from them might sound like this: "We make great computers. They're beautifully designed, simple to use and user friendly. Want to buy one?" "Meh." That's how most of us communicate. That's how most marketing and sales are done, that's how we communicate interpersonally. We say what we do, we say how we're different or better and we expect some sort of a behavior, a purchase, a vote, something like that. Here's our new law firm: We have the best lawyers with the biggest clients, we always perform for our clients. Here's our new car: It gets great gas mileage, it has leather seats. Buy our car. But it's uninspiring.

03:49
Here's how Apple actually communicates. "Everything we do, we believe in challenging the status quo. We believe in thinking differently. The way we challenge the status quo is by making our products beautifully designed, simple to use and user friendly. We just happen to make great computers. Want to buy one?" Totally different, right? You're ready to buy a computer from me. I just reversed the order of the information. What it proves to us is that people don't buy what you do; people buy why you do it.

04:24
This explains why every single person in this room is perfectly comfortable buying a computer from Apple. But we're also perfectly comfortable buying an MP3 player from Apple, or a phone from Apple, or a DVR from Apple. As I said before, Apple's just a computer company. Nothing distinguishes them structurally from any of their competitors. Their competitors are equally qualified to make all of these products. In fact, they tried. A few years ago, Gateway came out with flat-screen TVs. They're eminently qualified to make flat-screen TVs. They've been making flat-screen monitors for years. Nobody bought one. Dell came out with MP3 players and PDAs, and they make great quality products, and they can make perfectly well-designed products -- and nobody bought one. In fact, talking about it now, we can't even imagine buying an MP3 player from Dell. Why would you buy one from a computer company? But we do it every day. People don't buy what you do; they buy why you do it. The goal is not to do business with everybody who needs what you have. The goal is to do business with people who believe what you believe.

05:36
Here's the best part: None of what I'm telling you is my opinion. It's all grounded in the tenets of biology. Not psychology, biology. If you look at a cross-section of the human brain, from the top down, the human brain is actually broken into three major components that correlate perfectly with the golden circle. Our newest brain, our Homo sapien brain, our neocortex, corresponds with the "what" level. The neocortex is responsible for all of our rational and analytical thought and language. The middle two sections make up our limbic brains, and our limbic brains are responsible for all of our feelings, like trust and loyalty. It's also responsible for all human behavior, all decision-making, and it has no capacity for language.

06:24
In other words, when we communicate from the outside in, yes, people can understand vast amounts of complicated information like features and benefits and facts and figures. It just doesn't drive behavior. When we can communicate from the inside out, we're talking directly to the part of the brain that controls behavior, and then we allow people to rationalize it with the tangible things we say and do. This is where gut decisions come from. Sometimes you can give somebody all the facts and figures, and they say, "I know what all the facts and details say, but it just doesn't feel right." Why would we use that verb, it doesn't "feel" right? Because the part of the brain that controls decision-making doesn't control language. The best we can muster up is, "I don't know. It just doesn't feel right." Or sometimes you say you're leading with your heart or soul. I hate to break it to you, those aren't other body parts controlling your behavior. It's all happening here in your limbic brain, the part of the brain that controls decision-making and not language.

07:18
But if you don't know why you do what you do, and people respond to why you do what you do, then how will you ever get people to vote for you, or buy something from you, or, more importantly, be loyal and want to be a part of what it is that you do. The goal is not just to sell to people who need what you have; the goal is to sell to people who believe what you believe. The goal is not just to hire people who need a job; it's to hire people who believe what you believe. I always say that, you know, if you hire people just because they can do a job, they'll work for your money, but if they believe what you believe, they'll work for you with blood and sweat and tears. Nowhere else is there a better example than with the Wright brothers.

08:03
Most people don't know about Samuel Pierpont Langley. And back in the early 20th century, the pursuit of powered man flight was like the dot com of the day. Everybody was trying it. And Samuel Pierpont Langley had, what we assume, to be the recipe for success. Even now, you ask people, "Why did your product or why did your company fail?" and people always give you the same permutation of the same three things: under-capitalized, the wrong people, bad market conditions. It's always the same three things, so let's explore that. Samuel Pierpont Langley was given 50,000 dollars by the War Department to figure out this flying machine. Money was no problem. He held a seat at Harvard and worked at the Smithsonian and was extremely well-connected; he knew all the big minds of the day. He hired the best minds money could find and the market conditions were fantastic. The New York Times followed him around everywhere, and everyone was rooting for Langley. Then how come we've never heard of Samuel Pierpont Langley?

09:04
A few hundred miles away in Dayton, Ohio, Orville and Wilbur Wright, they had none of what we consider to be the recipe for success. They had no money; they paid for their dream with the proceeds from their bicycle shop. Not a single person on the Wright brothers' team had a college education, not even Orville or Wilbur. And The New York Times followed them around nowhere.

09:27
The difference was, Orville and Wilbur were driven by a cause, by a purpose, by a belief. They believed that if they could figure out this flying machine, it'll change the course of the world. Samuel Pierpont Langley was different. He wanted to be rich, and he wanted to be famous. He was in pursuit of the result. He was in pursuit of the riches. And lo and behold, look what happened. The people who believed in the Wright brothers' dream worked with them with blood and sweat and tears. The others just worked for the paycheck. They tell stories of how every time the Wright brothers went out, they would have to take five sets of parts, because that's how many times they would crash before supper.

10:08
And, eventually, on December 17th, 1903, the Wright brothers took flight, and no one was there to even experience it. We found out about it a few days later. And further proof that Langley was motivated by the wrong thing: the day the Wright brothers took flight, he quit. He could have said, "That's an amazing discovery, guys, and I will improve upon your technology," but he didn't. He wasn't first, he didn't get rich, he didn't get famous, so he quit.

longest_response:
El texto habla sobre el concepto de "the golden circle" (el círculo de oro) y cómo algunos líderes y organizaciones inspiran a las personas while others don't. The golden circle consiste en tres preguntas: ¿Por qué? (por qué existe tu organización o líder), ¿Cómo? (cómo logras tu propósito) y ¿Qué? (qué productos o servicios ofreces). La mayoría de las personas y organizaciones saben qué hacen, algunas saben cómo lo hacen, pero muy pocas saben por qué lo hacen. Según el autor, las organizaciones y líderes inspiradores piensan, actúan y communicentradas en el por qué, mientras que las demás lo hacen desde el exterior hacia el interior, primero explicando qué hacen y luego, si es el caso, cómo lo hacen.

El autor utiliza ejemplos como Apple, Martin Luther King y los hermanos Wright para ilustrar su punto. Explica que Apple no vende productos, sino una filosofía y una forma de ver el mundo. Martin Luther King no sólo era un gran orador, sino que estaba impulsado por una causa y una convicción profundas. Los hermanos Wright eran driven por una creencia de que su éxito cambiaría el mundo. En cada caso, su éxito se basa en el "por qué" detrás de sus acciones, no solo en qué hicieron.

La idea del autor está respaldada por la biología, afirma que la estructura del cerebro humano se correlaciona con el círculo de oro. La parte externa del cerebro (neocórtex) es responsable del pensamiento racional y analítico, mientras que la parte interna (cerebro límbico) es responsable de las emociones, la lealtad y la toma de decisiones. Cuando las personas y organizaciones comunican desde el "por qué", hablan directamente a la parte del cerebro que controla la conducta y permite que las personas racionalicen su decisión con la información tangible.

En resumen, el texto argumenta que las organizaciones y líderes inspiradores piensan, actúan y communicandos el "por qué" detrás de sus acciones, en lugar del "qué" o el "cómo". Esta forma de pensar y comunicarse es más efectiva para inspirar a las personas y crear lealtad, y está respaldada por la biología.
shortest_response: El texto habla sobre el concepto de "the golden circle" (el círculo de oro) y cómo algunos líderes e innovadores exitosos, como Apple, Martin Luther King y los hermanos Wright, piensan, actúan y se comunican de manera diferente a la mayoría. La idea central es que estos líderes tienen una claridad interna sobre el "por qué" de su existencia y su misión, y comunican desde adentro hacia afuera, en oposición a la mayoría de las personas y organizaciones que lo hacen al revés, centrándose en los "qué" y "cómo". El texto sugiere que el éxito y la inspiración vienen de operar desde un lugar de convicciones profundas y un propósito claro. Además, se menciona que este enfoque está respaldado por la biología y la forma en que funciona el cerebro humano. Las organizaciones y líderes exitosos no intentan llegar a todo el mundo, sino a aquellos que compartan sus creencias y valores.

prompt_text: Are there any experimental treatment plans?
longest_response:
I don't have personal access to real-time information or databases, so I can't provide the most recent experimental treatment plans. However, as of the time of my last update, there are several experimental treatment plans for depression. 

1. Ketamine: Ketamine is an FDA-approved anesthetic that has been found to have rapid antidepressant effects in some patients with treatment-resistant depression. It's often administered intravenously in a clinical setting.

2. Psychedelic Therapy: Research is being conducted on the use of psychedelics, such as psilocybin and ayahuasca, in conjunction with therapy for the treatment of depression. 

3. Deep Brain Stimulation: This is a surgical procedure where electrodes are implanted in certain areas of the brain and stimulated with electric current to help regulate mood. It's typically used as a last resort for people with severe depression who have not responded to other treatments.

4. Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation: This is a non-invasive procedure that uses magnetic fields to stimulate nerve cells in the brain to improve symptoms of depression.

5. Gene Therapy: Early research is being done on the use of gene therapy to treat depression. This involves using genes to produce proteins that can help regulate mood.

6. mTOR inhibitors: These are drugs that block a protein called mTOR which is thought to play a role in depression. Early research has shown some promising results.

7. Spravato (Esketamine): This is a nasal spray form of ketamine that was approved by the FDA in 2019 for treatment-resistant depression.

Please consult with a healthcare provider for information about the most current experimental treatments for depression.
shortest_response:

It's important for anyone considering participation in a clinical trial to discuss it thoroughly with their healthcare provider and to understand the potential benefits and risks. prompt_text:
April 27, 2022

Building the Discovery Engine

In this note I want to introduce the concept of Facebook as a “discovery engine,” which is a helpful mental model to frame the current focus of our long-term strategy. It also helps contextualize our product priorities, which we’ll continue to evolve over time to emphasize our near-term focus areas.

I encourage you to read the entire note, but if you just want the TL:DR here it is:

Our vision is for Facebook to be a place where everyone can belong, though the power of community. We define our four durable strategic pillars to accomplish this by helping people:

Find, enjoy and create interesting content.
Strengthen their relationships.
Create communities - both big and small.
Realize economic opportunities.
While our strategy is designed to stand the test of time, our execution and focus must be responsive to the needs of the current moment. Today we see a shift towards social media products serving as “discovery engines.” We’re sharing an updated articulation of our near-term priorities that are aimed at strengthening the Facebook discovery engine. These are:

Make Reels successful.
Build world class recommendations technology.
Unlock messaging-based sharing.
Alongside our product priorities, we’ll continue to prioritize culture changes to support the “Trustworthy, People-Centric, and Unified” approach to product development that we announced in January of this year.
Summarize this message
longest_response: Facebook's long-term vision is to be a "place where everyone can belong, through the power of community," with four strategic pillars: helping people find, enjoy and create interesting content; strengthen relationships; create communities; and realize economic opportunities. In response to the shift towards social media products acting as "discovery engines," Facebook has updated its near-term priorities to strengthen its discovery engine, which include making Reels successful, building world-class recommendations technology, and unlocking messaging-based sharing. Additionally, Facebook will continue to prioritize culture changes to support a "Trustworthy, People-Centric, and Unified" approach to product development.
shortest_response: Facebook's long-term strategy is focused on becoming a "discovery engine" to help people find, enjoy, and create interesting content, strengthen relationships, create communities, and realize economic opportunities. Their near-term priorities are making Reels successful, building world-class recommendations technology, and unlocking messaging-based sharing. Additionally, Facebook will continue to prioritize culture changes to support a "Trustworthy, People-Centric, and Unified" approach to product development.

It appears you have provided a SQL query that selects various fields, primarily focused on the "fb\_activity\_offers" table and the "targeting -> flexible\_spec -> 0 -> interests" array. The query also joins other tables such as "fb\_template\_adsets", "fb\_template\_campaigns", and "fb\_templates". The selection includes the current date, activity ID, and interest IDs and names. The query filters the data where "offering\_id" equals "CLICKS" and orders the results.

I've formatted the query for better readability:

```sql
SELECT 
    TO_CHAR(CURRENT_DATE, 'DD/MM/YYYY') AS date,
    fb_activity_offers.provider_activity_ref AS activity_id,
    targeting -> 'flexible_spec' -> 0 -> 'interests'-> 0 ->> 'id' AS interest_id_0,
    targeting -> 'flexible_spec' -> 0 -> 'interests'-> 0 ->> 'name' AS interest_name_0,
    -- (More interest fields followed)
    targeting -> 'flexible_spec' -> 0 -> 'interests'-> 33 ->> 'name' AS interest_name_33
FROM fb_template_adsets
LEFT JOIN fb_template_campaigns ON fb_template_campaigns.id = fb_template_adsets.template_campaign_id
LEFT JOIN fb_templates ON fb_templates.id = fb_template_campaigns.template_id
LEFT JOIN fb_activity_offers ON fb_activity_offers.id = fb_templates.activity_offer_id
WHERE offering_id = 'CLICKS'
ORDER BY -- (Ordering expression is missing)
```

To improve the query, I would recommend:

1. Adding an ordering expression in the `ORDER BY` clause.
2. Limiting the number of columns selected to only what is necessary.
3. Consider using JSON functions to extract interest fields instead of hardcoding the keys. This can make the query more versatile and easier to maintain.

Here's an example using JSON functions:

```sql
SELECT 
    TO_CHAR(CURRENT_DATE, 'DD/MM/YYYY') AS date,
    fb_activity_offers.provider_activity_ref AS activity_id,
    jsonb_array_elements(targeting -> 'flexible_spec' -> 0 -> 'interests') AS interest
FROM fb_template_adsets
LEFT JOIN fb_template_campaigns ON fb_template_campaigns.id = fb_template_adsets.template_campaign_id
LEFT JOIN fb_templates ON fb_templates.id = fb_template_campaigns.template_id
LEFT JOIN fb_activity_offers ON fb_activity_offers.id = fb_templates.activity_offer_id
WHERE offering_id = 'CLICKS'
ORDER BY date;
```

This query uses `jsonb_array_elements` to extract each interest as a separate row, reducing the number of columns needed. Keep in mind that this may not be the exact structure needed for your output; you can adjust it accordingly.

Here is a 3-month (12 week) training program that you can follow using the equipment in your home gym. This program is designed to help novice lifters build functional strength using a linear progression model, starting with the lowest weight ranges and gradually increasing over time.

**Equipment needed:**

* Low row cable pulley system
* Pull-down bar
* Pull-up bar
* Ab wheel
* Dumbbells (10-55 lbs)
* Power rack

	+ Dumbbell overhead press: 3 sets of 8-10 reps (start with 10 lb dumbbells)
	+ Pull-ups: 3 sets of max reps (use body weight or add weight as needed)
	+ Ab wheel roll-outs: 3 sets of 8-10 reps

* Day 2:
	+ Low row: 4 sets of 8-10 reps (increase weight by 5 lbs if able)
	+ Pull-downs: 4 sets of 8-10 reps (increase weight by 5 lbs if able)
	+ Dumbbell deadlifts: 4 sets of 8-10 reps (increase weight by 5 lbs if able)
	+ Dumbbell overhead press: 4 sets of 8-10 reps (increase weight by 5 lbs if able)
	+ Pull-ups: 4 sets of max reps (use body weight or add weight as needed)
	+ Ab wheel roll-outs: 3 sets of 10-12 reps

**Weeks 9-12:**

* Day 1:
	+ Low row: 5 sets of 8-10 reps (increase weight by 5 lbs if able)
	+ Pull-downs: 5 sets of 8-10 reps (increase weight by 5 lbs if able)
	+ Dumbbell squats: 5 sets of 8-10 reps (increase weight by 5 lbs if able)

* Day 2:

	+ Dumbbell deadlifts: 5 sets of 8-10 reps (increase weight by 5 lbs if able)

	+ Pull-ups: 5 sets of max reps (use body weight or add weight as needed)
	+ Ab wheel roll-outs: 4 sets of 12-15 reps

A few things to keep in mind:

* Always warm up before starting your workout and cool down afterwards.
* Make sure to use proper form and technique on all exercises to avoid injury.
* Increase weight only when you are able to complete all sets and reps with good form.
* If you are unable to complete the recommended number of sets and reps with good form, decrease the weight.

shortest_response:
Here is a 3-month, 2-day a week training program that focuses on functional strength building and is safe for novices. This program uses a linear progression model, starting with lower weight ranges and gradually increasing the weight over time.

Day 1:

1. Warm-up: 5-10 minutes of light cardio (jogging in place, jumping jacks, etc.)
2. Dumbbell Squats: 3 sets of 8-12 reps, starting with 10 lb dumbbells and increasing by 5 lbs every week.
3. Dumbbell Bench Press: 3 sets of 8-12 reps, starting with 10 lb dumbbells and increasing by 5 lbs every week.
4. Low Row: 3 sets of 8-12 reps, starting with the lowest weight setting and increasing by 10 lbs every other week.
5. Dumbbell Bicep Curls: 3 sets of 8-12 reps, starting with 10 lb dumbbells and increasing by 5 lbs every week.
6. Ab Wheel Rollouts: 3 sets of 8-12 reps
7. Cool-down: 5-10 minutes of stretching

Day 2:

1. Warm-up: 5-10 minutes of light cardio
2. Pull-ups: 3 sets of max reps, starting with bodyweight only and adding a weight belt with a plate every other week.
3. Dumbbell Deadlifts: 3 sets of 8-12 reps, starting with 10 lb dumbbells and increasing by 5 lbs every week.
4. Pull-downs: 3 sets of 8-12 reps, starting with the lowest weight setting and increasing by 10 lbs every other week.
5. Dumbbell Shoulder Press: 3 sets of 8-12 reps, starting with 10 lb dumbbells and increasing by 5 lbs every week.
6. Ab Wheel Rollouts: 3 sets of 8-12 reps
7. Cool-down: 5-10 minutes of stretching

Note: It is important to gradually increase the weight and number of sets and reps as you progress in strength. It is also important to use proper form and technique when lifting weights, and to always warm-up and cool-down before and after workouts. Consult a doctor or a certified personal trainer before starting any new workout program.

prompt_text: I would like you to be a DM for a D&D campaign and world that you generate
longest_response:
Welcome, adventurer, to the world of Theries, a land of magic and mystery, where gods walk among mortals and great empires rise and fall. In this campaign, you will traverse treacherous landscapes, delve into ancient ruins, and confront powerful foes in your quest for fame, fortune, and power.

Before we begin, let me set the scene:

The year is 1493 DR, and the world of Theries is in turmoil. The once-mighty Empire of Tharros has fallen, and its former territories are now fractured into a dozen smaller kingdoms, each vying for power and resources. In the power vacuum left by Tharros' collapse, new threats have emerged, seeking to fill the void and impose their own tyranny upon the world.

In the north, the barbarian tribes of the Frostlands have united under a charismatic chieftain, who dreams of marching south and conquering the warm lands to the south. In the west, the pirate lords of the Serpent's Teeth Archipelago have formed a powerful alliance, raiding coastal towns and villages with impunity. And in the east, the elusive and mysterious Shadowmancers, a cult of necromancers and dark sorcerers, seek to plunge the world into eternal night and rule over the ashes.

Amidst these dangers, there are still those who seek to maintain the balance and protect the innocent. The Free Cities of the Inner Sea, a confederation of independent city-states, have banded together to form a bulwark against the chaos that threatens to consume the world. And in the heart of the empire, a secretive order of knights, the Order of the Golden Dawn, works tirelessly to uncover the truth behind the collapse of Tharros and bring those responsible to justice.

As a adventurer, you have been granted an audience with the leaders of the Free Cities, who have tasked you with a critical mission: to investigate the ruins of Tharros and uncover the secrets of its collapse. They believe that the key to restoring order to the world lies in the heart of the fallen empire, but the road ahead is fraught with danger.

Before you set out on your journey, you will need to assemble your party. You may choose from a variety of races and classes, each with its own unique abilities and strengths. You may be a fierce warrior, wielding a mighty sword and shield; a cunning rogue, skilled in the art of thievery and deception; a wise and powerful wizard, able to cast devastating spells and bend the very fabric of reality to your will; or a pious cleric, calling upon the power of the gods to heal your allies and smite your enemies.

Once your party is assembled, you will set out from the Free Cities and journey to the ruins of Tharros, a journey that will take you through treacherous mountains, dark forests, and desolate wastelands. Along the way, you will encounter friend and foe alike, and you will have to make difficult choices that will determine the fate of the world.

As you explore the ruins of Tharros, you will uncover ancient secrets and hidden truths, and you will come face to face with the forces that brought about the empire's downfall. You will have to overcome powerful enemies, from giant monsters to shadowy assassins, and you will have to outwit cunning traps and insidious puzzles.

But the challenges you face will not be limited to the physical realm. As you delve deeper into the ruins, you will uncover a dark and sinister conspiracy, one that threatens to plunge the world into darkness and despair. You will have to confront the leaders of the Shadowmancers, who seek to use the power of Tharros to achieve their own nefarious ends.

In the end, it will be up to you and your party to decide the fate of the world. Will you be able to uncover the secrets of Tharros and restore order to the world, or will you fall to the forces of chaos and darkness? The choice is yours.

Now, adventurer, the time has come to begin your journey. Gather your party, and set out for the ruins of Tharros. May the gods be with you, and may your blade be true.

prompt_text: I am using a wordpress with woo-commerce using stripe payment gateway. I want my customer to have a 1 year membership where he can purchase a product and get it auto-renewed but on 5th month he should get an option to exchange the product and continue untill the membership is active. My question is how should i achieve it and explain its logic.
shortest_response:
To achieve this functionality, you would need to use a combination of plugins and custom code in Wordpress and WooCommerce. Here's a possible approach:

1. **Membership Plugin:** You can use a membership plugin, such as "Paid Memberships Pro" or "WooCommerce Memberships," to create a one-year membership product. These plugins will allow you to set up recurring payments and membership periods.
2. **Auto-Renewal:** For the auto-renewal of the product, you can use WooCommerce Subscriptions plugin. This plugin allows you to create and manage products with recurring payments. It also has built-in support for Stripe.
3. **Product Exchange:** For the product exchange feature, you might need to use a custom solution. This could involve creating a custom plugin or hiring a developer to create one for you. Here's a possible logic:

a. After the 5th month of the membership, the user gets an option (maybe an email notification with a link) to exchange the product.

b. If the user chooses to exchange, they can select a new product from a list of eligible products.

c. Once the new product is selected, the system automatically updates the user's subscription to include the new product and remove the old one.

d. The subscription period remains the same, and the user continues to be billed for the membership.

e. If the user doesn't choose to exchange, they continue with the original product until the membership ends.

4. **Continuation of Membership:** The membership continues until the one-year period is over, and the user gets automatically billed for the renewal.

Remember, this is a complex feature, and you might need to hire a developer if you're not comfortable with coding. Also, thorough testing is required to ensure everything works as expected.

prompt_text: Could you provide me an example of how a Cloud technical pre study looks like?
longest_response:
Sure, I'd be happy to provide an example of a Cloud technical pre-study. A technical pre-study is an analysis of the technical requirements and constraints of a proposed cloud-based solution. It typically includes the following elements:

1. **Business Requirements:** A summary of the business problem or opportunity that the cloud-based solution will address. This section should also include any high-level requirements or constraints that will impact the technical design.

Example: The company's on-premises data center is nearing capacity, and the cost of expanding it is prohibitive. The company is considering migrating some or all of its workloads to the cloud.

2. **Technical Requirements:** A detailed list of the technical requirements for the proposed solution. This section should include information about the workloads that will be migrated, the expected performance and availability requirements, and any compliance or security requirements.

Example: The company has identified several workloads that are good candidates for migration to the cloud. These workloads include a customer relationship management (CRM) system, a data warehouse, and a web application. The CRM system must be available 99.95% of the time, the data warehouse must be able to handle a high volume of queries, and the web application must be compliant with Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS) regulations.

3. **Cloud Provider Evaluation:** A comparison of different cloud providers based on the technical requirements. This section should include information about the services offered by each provider, the cost of those services, and any potential limitations or constraints.

Example: The company has evaluated several cloud providers and has narrowed down the options to two: AWS and Azure. AWS offers a wider range of services, but Azure has a more favorable pricing model for the company's expected usage patterns.

4. **Technical Design:** A detailed technical design for the proposed solution. This section should include information about the architecture of the solution, the deployment model (e.g., public, private, hybrid), and any specific cloud services or tools that will be used.

Example: The company has decided to use a hybrid cloud model, with the CRM system and data warehouse hosted on AWS and the web application hosted on Azure. The solution will use AWS Direct Connect to establish a dedicated network connection between the on-premises data center and AWS, and Azure ExpressRoute to establish a similar connection with Azure. The web application will be deployed in Azure App Service, and the CRM system and data warehouse will be deployed in AWS Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) instances.

5. **Security and Compliance:** A discussion of the security and compliance requirements for the proposed solution. This section should include information about any measures that will be taken to ensure data privacy, integrity, and protection.

Example: The company will use AWS Key Management Service (KMS) to manage encryption keys for the CRM system and data warehouse. Access to the EC2 instances will be restricted to authorized users, and all data in transit will be encrypted using Secure Sockets Layer/Transport Layer Security (SSL/TLS). Azure App Service will be configured to use Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) for authentication and authorization.

6. **Migration Strategy:** A plan for migrating the workloads to the cloud. This section should include information about any tools or techniques that will be used to facilitate the migration, as well as a timeline for completing the migration.

Example: The company will use AWS Server Migration Service and Azure Migrate to migrate the workloads to the cloud. The migration will be performed in phases, with the CRM system and data warehouse migrated first, followed by the web application. The migration is expected to take three months to complete.

7. **Cost and ROI:** A detailed analysis of the cost and return on investment (ROI) for the proposed solution. This section should include information about the upfront and ongoing costs of the solution, as well as any potential savings or benefits.

Example: The upfront cost of the proposed solution is estimated to be $500,000, with ongoing costs of $100,000 per month. The company expects to save $200,000 per year in data center costs, and to realize a ROI of 30% over three years.

8. **Assumptions and Risks:** A discussion of any assumptions or risks associated with the proposed solution. This section should include information about any potential issues or challenges that may arise during the implementation or operation of the solution.

Example: The company assumes that the network connection between the data center and the cloud providers will be reliable and performant. A potential risk is that the migration may disrupt the company's operations, and that the new solution may not meet the company's performance or availability requirements.

I hope that gives you a good idea of what a Cloud technical pre-study might look like. Of course, the specific contents and format of the pre-study will depend on the particular needs and constraints of the proposed solution and the organization.
shortest_response:
Sure! Here is an example of what a Cloud technical pre-study might look like:

1. Executive Summary: A brief overview of the project, including the goals and objectives of the pre-study.
2. Current State Analysis: A description of the existing IT environment, including any current pain points or challenges. This section should also include an analysis of the organization's readiness for cloud migration.
3. Requirements Definition: A detailed list of the technical requirements for the cloud solution, including performance, security, compliance, and integration needs.
4. Cloud Provider Evaluation: A comparison of different cloud providers based on the organization's requirements, including an analysis of cost, performance, and feature sets.
5. Architecture and Design: A proposed architecture and design for the cloud solution, including details on how data will be migrated, how applications will be hosted and how the solution will be managed and monitored.
6. Implementation Plan: A detailed plan for the migration to the cloud, including timelines, resources, and milestones.
7. Training and Support: A plan for training staff on the new cloud solution and providing ongoing support.
8. Risks and Mitigation: An identification of potential risks and a plan for mitigating those risks.
9. Cost-Benefit Analysis: A detailed cost-benefit analysis, including an estimate of the total cost of ownership and a return on investment calculation.
10. Recommendations: A summary of the findings and recommendations for next steps.

Please note that this is a general example, and the actual pre-study will depend on the organization and the specific project.

For a fruitful and insightful discussion on adaptive cycles in complex adaptive systems, with a focus on comparing ecosystems and human systems such as countries, consider inviting the following experts:

1. Dr. Brian Walker: A renowned ecologist, Walker is a former President of the Association for Environmental Studies and Sciences. He has extensively studied resilience in social-ecological systems and is a co-author of the influential book "Resilience Thinking."

Website: [Brian Walker's website](https://www.resalliance.org/brian-walker)

2. Dr. Fikret Berkes: Berkes is a professor at the University of Manitoba and has expertise in the fields of ecology, anthropology, and resource management. His work focuses on the interconnections between ecosystems and human communities, particularly Indigenous peoples.

Website: [Fikret Berkes' website](https://umanitoba.ca/faculties/social_work/dept/rm/faculty/berkes.html)

3. Dr. Elinor Ostrom: Although she passed away in 2012, Ostrom's work remains influential in the study of complex adaptive systems, human systems, and the governance of common pool resources. Consider inviting scholars or practitioners well-versed in Ostrom's work to contribute to the discussion.

[Elinor Ostrom's official website](https://www.elinorostrom.com/)

4. Dr. Sidney G. Winter: A professor emeritus at the University of Pennsylvania, Winter is an institutional economist who has explored the role of organizational capabilities and routines in the behavior of firms, industries, and economy-wide systems.

Website: [Sidney Winter's website](https://repository.upenn.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1031&context=marketing_faculty)

5. Dr. Joseph Tainter: Tainter is a complexity specialist, with a focus on understanding the collapse of complex societies and their relationship to resource depletion, environmental degradation, and sociopolitical institutions.

Website: [Joseph Tainter's website](https://www.complexity-and-recovery.com/)

6. Dr. Wendy J. Schiller: A political scientist at Brown University, Schiller's research focuses on American political institutions, electoral politics, and representation. She can provide valuable insights on the resilience and adaptive capacity of human political systems.

Website: [Wendy J. Schiller's website](https://watson.brown.edu/people/faculty/schiller)

7. Dr. Frances Westley: An influential scholar in the study of social innovation and complex systems, Westley is a Professor of Strategic Management at the University of Waterloo.

Website: [Frances Westley's website](https://uwaterloo.ca/strategic-management/people-profiles/frances-westley)

8. Dr. Daniel F. Doak: An ecologist at the University of Colorado-Boulder, Doak has worked on questions related to population viability, conservation biology, and the adaptive cycle in the Greater Yellowstone Area. His expertise in ecology and wildlife habitat management is highly relevant to the discussion.

Website: [Daniel F. Doak's website](https://www.colorado.edu/ecology/profile/daniel-f-doak-phd)

It is important to remember that inviting a diverse group of experts with various backgrounds and perspectives will enrich the discussion and facilitate more comprehensive and informed insights into adaptive cycles in complex adaptive systems.
shortest_response:
To have a fruitful discussion on adaptive cycles in complex adaptive systems and compare ecosystems with human systems such as countries, you might consider inviting the following experts:

3. Dr. Crawford Stanley Holling - He is considered the father of resilience theory and panarchy. He was a Canadian ecologist who made significant contributions to the study of adaptive cycles in complex systems.

5. Dr. Frances Westley - She is a professor of social innovation and the director of the Waterloo Institute for Social Innovation and Resilience. Westley has studied the adaptive cycle in social systems and its relationship to innovation and resilience.
6. Dr. Marten Scheffer - A professor of aquatic ecology and disorder and complexity, Scheffer has written extensively on early warning signs of critical transitions in complex systems, including ecosystems and human systems.
7. Dr. Elinor Ostrom - She was a political economist who won the Nobel Prize in Economics for her work on the governance of common-pool resources. Ostrom's work on institutional analysis of complex systems is highly relevant to the study of adaptive cycles in human systems.

These experts come from a range of disciplines, including ecology, environmental studies, marine biology, sociology, and economics. They have all made significant contributions to the study of adaptive cycles in complex systems, and their perspectives would be invaluable in a discussion comparing ecosystems with human systems such as countries.

longest_response:
Certainly! I'll do my best to provide you with factual information for your trip. Here are some must-visit tourist destinations and nearby cities, along with some local culture and customs:

1. Paris, France:
* The Eiffel Tower, Louvre Museum, Notre-Dame Cathedral, and Montmartre are popular tourist destinations.
* The local language is French and it is customary to greet people with a simple "bonjour" (hello) or "bonsoir" (good evening) when entering shops or restaurants.
* It is also customary to say "merci" (thank you) and "au revoir" (goodbye) when leaving.
* French cuisine is renowned worldwide, with classic dishes such as croissants, baguettes, escargot, and croque monsieurs.

2. Rome, Italy:
* The Colosseum, Roman Forum, Vatican City, and Trevi Fountain are popular tourist destinations.
* The local language is Italian and it is customary to greet people with a simple "buongiorno" (good day) or "buonasera" (good evening) when entering shops or restaurants.
* It is also customary to say "grazie" (thank you) and "arrivederci" (goodbye) when leaving.
* Italian cuisine is famous for its pasta, pizza, and gelato.

3. Tokyo, Japan:
* The Tokyo Skytree, Meiji Shrine, Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden, and Akihabara district are popular tourist destinations.
* The local language is Japanese and it is customary to bow when greeting someone, especially in formal situations.
* It is also customary to remove your shoes when entering someone's home or a temple.
* Japanese cuisine is renowned for its sushi, ramen, and tempura.

4. New York City, USA:
* The Statue of Liberty, Central Park, Times Square, and Metropolitan Museum of Art are popular tourist destinations.
* The local language is English and it is customary to greet people with a simple "hello" when entering shops or restaurants.
* It is also customary to say "please" and "thank you" when making requests or receiving assistance.
* American cuisine is diverse, with classic dishes such as hamburgers, hot dogs, and pizza.

5. Sydney, Australia:
* The Sydney Opera House, Sydney Harbour Bridge, Bondi Beach, and Taronga Zoo are popular tourist destinations.
* The local language is English and it is customary to greet people with a simple "hello" when entering shops or restaurants.
* It is also customary to say "please" and "thank you" when making requests or receiving assistance.
* Australian cuisine is diverse, with classic dishes such as meat pies, sausage rolls, and vegemite sandwiches.

These are just a few examples of popular tourist destinations and local customs. It's always a good idea to do some research and learn about the local culture and customs before traveling to a new place.

prompt_text: I'd like to create a SwiftUI app that uses SceneKit and a physics engine to create a pseduo-3D model of a black hole, with its accretion disk properly displayed swirling around it in a ring and also gravitationally lensed as a ring perpendicular to the actual disk from the viewer's perspective. I am familiar with SwiftUI and Xcode already. I have a project open and ready to go. I don't have any 3D model files to use for a black hole, but I am thinking we can simulate it using SceneKit and other libraries if needed. We can write out the code step by step, we don't want you to write output that will be truncated.
shortest_response:
Sure, I'd be happy to help you with that! Here's a rough outline of the steps you can follow to create a SwiftUI app with a pseudo-3D model of a black hole and its accretion disk.

Step 1: Set up your SwiftUI app
--------------------------------

Create a new SwiftUI app in Xcode and set up your basic app structure, including any views you need to display your 3D model.

Step 2: Create a SceneKit scene
-------------------------------

In your SwiftUI view, create a new SceneKit scene using `SCNScene`. This will serve as the container for your 3D model.

Step 3: Add a camera to the scene
---------------------------------

Add a camera to the scene using `SCNCameraNode`. You can position the camera to view your black hole and accretion disk from a suitable angle.

Step 4: Create a black hole
----------------------------

To simulate a black hole, you can create a sphere using `SCNSphere` and apply a material with a dark color and high roughness to make it look like a black object. To give the impression of depth and curvature, you can apply a texture with a repeating pattern of concentric circles or lines.

Step 5: Create an accretion disk
--------------------------------

To create an accretion disk, you can use `SCNParticleSystem` to generate a large number of small particles that orbit the black hole. You can use physics engines like `SCNPhysicsWorld` or `SCNPhysicsVehicle` to simulate the motion of the particles and keep them in orbit around the black hole.

You may also want to apply a texture to the particles to make them look like gas or dust.

Step 6: Add gravitational lensing
---------------------------------

To add gravitational lensing, you can use the positional and directional information of incoming rays of light to calculate the deflection angle, and then modify the outgoing direction of the rays accordingly. This will cause light from objects behind the black hole to be bent around it, giving the characteristic "ring" appearance of a black hole shadow.

You may want to use a physics engine or math library like GLM to help with the calculations.

Step 7: Add interactivity
--------------------------

Finally, you can add interactivity to your app to allow users to rotate or zoom in on the black hole. You can do this by updating the camera position and orientation based on user input.

Step 8: Fine-tune and optimize
------------------------------

Once you have all the basic elements in place, you can fine-tune the appearance and behavior of your black hole and accretion disk to make them look more realistic. You may also need to optimize the performance of your app to ensure smooth animation and interaction.

Good luck with your project, and feel free to ask if you have any questions or need further guidance!

3. Multimedia Presentation: Create a new row for the multimedia presentation and input the following details:

	* Subtotal: =[Projector Hire Fee + Screen Hire Fee]
4. Photographer and Videographer: Create a new row for the photographer and videographer and input the following details:
	* Photographer: [Insert Number of Hours]*[Hourly Rate]
	* Videographer: [Insert Number of Hours]*[Hourly Rate]
	* Subtotal: =[Photographer + Videographer]
5. Hamper/Gift: Create a new row for the hamper/gift and input the following details:

	* Certificate: [Insert Number of Certificates]*[Price per Certificate]

	* Decorations: [Insert Number of Decorations]*[Price per Decoration]

8. Total: Create a new row for the total and input the following details:
	* Total: =[Subtotal for Venue + Subtotal for Multimedia Presentation + Subtotal for Photographer and Videographer + Subtotal for Hamper/Gift + Subtotal for Food and Beverage + Subtotal for Transportation and Logistics]

Step 5: Basic Functions

1. Auto Sum: To calculate the total for the subtotals, select the cells with the subtotal and click on the "AutoSum" button in the "Editing" section of the Home tab.
2. Multiplication: To calculate the subtotal for the number of staff and rental fee, the hourly rate and number of hours for the photographer and videographer, and the price per head and number of staff for food and beverage, use the multiplication function by entering "=" followed by the first value, a "\*", and the second value.
3. Division: To calculate the hourly rate for the photographer and videographer, divide the total cost by the number of hours.
4. Subtraction: To calculate the net cost, subtract the total cost from the budget allocated for the event; enter "=" followed by the subtotal cell and a "-" sign, and then enter the budget allocated amount.

Step 6: Number Formatting (Currency)
Format all the cost and price cells to currency by selecting the cells, right-clicking and selecting "Format Cells." In the "Category" section, select "Currency" and choose your preferred format.

prompt_text: write about a steampunk city that has both a wondrous inventive side and a dark, dirty side
longest_response:
In the heart of the sprawling, clockwork metropolis of Aetherspire, the clanks and whirrs of ingenious contraptions create a symphony of innovation. The city, a marvel of steampunk ingenuity, is home to some of the most brilliant minds of the age, who ceaselessly toil to bring forth their next fantastical invention. The streets are lined with towering buildings of brass and iron, their facades adorned with intricate gears and smokestacks that billow plumes of steam into the air. Airships, equally magnificent, float through the skies, casting moving shadows over the city below.

Aetherspire is a place of wonder, where dreams become reality and the boundaries of science and magic intertwine. In the city's heart, the Grand Aetherium, a cathedral-like structure of shimmering copper, stands as a testament to human ambition. Here, inventors gather to exchange ideas and showcase their latest creations, from mechanical birds that soar through the skies to automatons that serve the city's denizens. The air is thick with the smell of oil and the hum of energy, as the Aetherium thrums with the power coursing through its very veins.

The city's inventors, known as the Aetherials, are revered as heroes and pioneers, their names etched into the annals of history. Their insatiable curiosity and boundless imagination drive them to push the limits of what is possible, creating machines and contraptions that defy logic and reason. Yet, for all its marvels, Aetherspire harbors a darker side, a grim underbelly where progress and prosperity cast long, unforgiving shadows.

Beneath the gleaming surface of Aetherspire, in the labyrinthine network of tunnels and workshops that make up the city's underbelly, a different world exists. Here, the air reeks of soot and sulfur, and the clang of hammer on metal echoes through the dimly lit corridors. This is the realm of the Tinkers, the skilled artisans who toil in the shadows, their hands blackened by grime and their brows furrowed with concentration.

The Tinkers are the unheralded backbone of Aetherspire, the ones who turn the dreams of the Aetherials into reality. They are the smiths and machinists who forge the components that drive the city's machines, the engineers who maintain the intricate network of pipes and gears that keep Aetherspire functioning. Yet, despite their invaluable contributions, the Tinkers remain in the shadows, their existence overlooked and undervalued by the city's elite.

The disparity between the Aetherials and the Tinkers is a stark reminder of the darker side of progress. The city's unquenchable thirst for innovation has led to a system where the talented few reap the rewards, while the many labor in obscurity, their efforts unrecognized and unrewarded. The Tinkers, though proud of their work, are all too aware of the inequity that exists within their society. They watch, silent and resentful, as the Aetherials bask in the adoration of the crowds, their names etched in the history books, while their own contributions go uncelebrated and unsung.

In the depths of Aetherspire's underbelly, whispers of discontent simmer, and unrest festers. The Tinkers, long accustomed to their lot in life, are beginning to question the status quo, to demand fairness and recognition for their efforts. And as the divide between the haves and the have-nots grows ever wider, so too does the potential for disaster.

For all its marvels and magnificence, Aetherspire is a city built on a foundation of sand, its prosperity and progress balanced precariously on the edge of a knife. As the Tinkers' discontent grows, so too does the risk of a catastrophic upheaval, one that could bring the city's shining edifice crashing down around them. And as the clash between the Aetherials and the Tinkers grows ever closer, the fate of Aetherspire hangs in the balance, teetering on the brink of chaos and destruction.

But even as the clouds of revolution gather, the spirit of invention that defines Aetherspire refuses to be extinguished. For every voice that calls for change, there are others that dream of a brighter future, of a world where the wonders of technology and magic are shared by all, without prejudice or partiality. It is this indomitable spirit, this unyielding desire to create and innovate, that has shaped Aetherspire into the city it is today, and it is this same spirit that will determine its fate tomorrow.

In the end, Aetherspire is a city of contrasts, a place where the brilliant and the downtrodden, the marvelous and the mundane, coexist in an uneasy alliance. It is a city that defies definition, a steampunk metropolis that is at once wondrous and gritty, innovative and corrupt, a testament to the limitless potential of human ingenuity and the darker side of progress. It is a city that, for better or worse, will forever remain a symbol of the dreams and desires, the triumphs and failures, of those who call it home.

As the sun sets over Aetherspire, casting the city in a golden glow that highlights the intricate details of its brass and iron façades, the sound of gears turning and steam hissing fills the air. The city is alive, its heart beating with the rhythm of progress, its soul alight with the fire of invention. And even as the shadows lengthen and the first stars begin to appear in the twilight sky, Aetherspire remains an enduring monument to the indomitable spirit of its people, a testament to their unwavering determination to create, to innovate, and to forge a brighter future in the heart of the steampunk metropolis they call home.

Aeternum is a city of towering spires and labyrinthine streets, where steam-powered machines chug and hiss, and airships float majestically through the smog-filled skies. The city is a marvel of human ingenuity, a testament to the limitless potential of technology and invention.

The inventors of Aeternum are some of the most brilliant minds in the world, and their creations are nothing short of miraculous. From steam-powered carriages that can travel at breakneck speeds to mechanical automatons that can perform complex tasks with ease, the people of Aeternum have harnessed the power of steam to create a world that is both wondrous and awe-inspiring.

But beneath the shiny veneer of progress and innovation, there lies a darker side to Aeternum. The city is also home to a vast network of factories and foundries, where the air is thick with soot and the ground is slick with oil.
